content:
ber 8, 2015
												To anyone considering buying this game, ask yourself two simple questions.Do I have friends that would play this with me? Do I like shooters and/or RPGs?If you answered yes to either of these questions, then you will enjoy this game. Playing with friends in this game is a great time, even if you dont want to get involved with the story, you will find that shooting your way around the world with up to three other friends is massivley enjoyable. However, boasting an incredibly solid campaign as this, delivering quirky characters and interesting dialogue, this games gives you pleanty of reason to actually get involved in the story. All in all, the campaign scores a 8.7/10 from me, as the multiple runthroughs that I went through did not have me pull my eyes out of my sockets from tedium. *cough* Borderlands 1 arid badlands*cough* The area that really makes this game shine is the DLCs. The dlcs from this game are, with the community in almost unanimous agreement, better than the actual campaign, which as I said before, is really great. Finish the game for the first time, then I wholeheartedly recommend you smack those dlcs. With actual raid bosses *cough* Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel and your single "Raid" boss which was just a rehash of the last boss(Which dont get me wrong, wasnt a bad boss, and the idea of doing on what is basically a higher risk for a higher reward  difficulty is nice, but thats what true and ultimate vault hunter mode are for, not the only raid boss slot in the game.)*cough* (Wow that was a really long cough...) left right and center (Which are basically titanic bosses that will test all of you and three friends abilites), these dlcs offer the game longevity to last you through your post game completion hours. If you are not planning on getting all of the dlc for monetary reasons or others, then I recomment that you buy the dlc's in this order as far as you want to go;Tiny Tina Assault on Dragon Keep. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME AND THEN SKIP THIS DLC. This, in my opinion, is the SINGLE BEST DLC I HAVE EVER PLAYED FOR ANY GAME EVER. This dlc is great. It retells the deals with Tiny Tinas grief and eventual acceptance of (spoilers I shall not say) and it does so in a fashion that runs you through a fantasy world filled with orcs and Dragons and sorcerers and loot, oh boy the loot... This DLC is the Borderlands 2 experience. Do not miss it. 10/10. Please find me a fault in this Dlc, for I can not find any off the top of my head.Torgues Campaign of Carnage.This add on campaign, the same as Tiny Tinas Campaign, adds on an additional plot that introduces you to one of the best Npcs in the history of gaming. You will never look at a torgue weapon the same again. 9.8/10.Captain Scarletts Pirate Booty.Yeh, I dont know, its alright, but it just doesnt quite have the same awesome feel to it as the other campaigns. I think I might be the desert backdrop and the lack of a really interesting and constantly recurring funny character, but it doesnt hold you as well as the previous two, despite still being enjoyable and quite lengthy. I would give it a 8.7/10Hammerlocks Hunt.Skip it. you are not missing out on anything. I know I sound very dismissove here, but the last boss is a ♥♥♥♥♥, as in the bullet reflecting, cowardly, annoying as hell ♥♥♥♥♥. Not to mention the raid boss, who is a collosal a-hole. Unavoidable novas and basically a giant Rabid Stalker, yeh...no, I think Ill pass, or maybe come back as a pimp when I level up my gunzerker... :resmile:Hammerlock does his best to be funny, and the pathetic attempt at being a main villain does come out more humourous than intimidating as intended, so if you enjoy Borderlands humour and want another chunk of gameplay you wont be dissapointed, but you also wont come out going, Wow, that was awesome!  7.2/10Finally, for all of you who made it to hear, well done, clearly you have a large attention span, you might actually get yourself a legit Norfleet one day. The character packs. Mechromancer and Psycho. This depends on what you intend to do with each of these chars. Up to level 72 WITHOUT OP levels, I would recommend the Psycho. He is probably the most satisfying of all the chars in game, you find yourself looking out for that satisfying crunch sound beneath your buzzaxe... However, if you intend on taking only one of these chars into OP 8, take the Mechromancer. This is because the Psycho is balanced through leveling, and as he stops leveling inside the OP levels, his melee damage starts to drop off, making him far less viable, especially compared to the Mechromancers anarchy stacks, making you an inaccurate but oneshotting machine, when I say one shttting, I mean one shotting minibosses one shotting. In summary, if you are looking at the game and thinking, "Hey, this looks pretty alright..." then do yourself a favor and buy it. And if you enjoy your first playthrough of the original campaign, do yourself a massive solid and get Tiny Tinas Dlc. You will not regret it. And if you are really loving the game, buy the Psycho, go Psycho and enjoy yourself while you do it. This is the best installment to the Borderlands franchise up until now, with the greatest campaign and longevity of them all. So do it.

content:
ry 14, 2014
												I will start by saying; I have been playing Borderlands2 for maybe about a week now. I currently have a level 18 Commando. Never did I touch the original Borderlands, and I always wanted to get into it. The commercials on TV always patronized me, and then one day, bam! Someone gifted it to me on Steam. I couldn't believe my eyes.It is now maybe 3 years later, that I have gotten myself into Borderlands 2 (which, guess what - was gifted to me!) with two other friends. I am absolutely in love.If you have ever played an MMORPG - the concept is sort of the same. You have to complete quests, and you unlock experience, currencies (Cash, Eridium [usable on black market]), weapons, class mods and whatnot. Of course, there is also DLC you can purchase to further customize your character -- but you do not even have to. You can also unlock OTHER character customizations just by playing.Loads of fun. Quests can sometimes be confusing on figuring out exactly just where to go, and controlling your first vehicle before you get the Bandit by mouse is EXTREMELY awkward for me.. the wheels don't move by A and S, it moves by the mouse. I know there's a term for that.. but I don't know what it is, and it is 2am in the morning.Please - get this game. I promise you you will thank me later. And if it's gifted to you - thank that person. I have my own thanks to give. :)

content:
er 22, 2013
												The hook of Borderlands 2,  is the loot. Guns, ammo, character skins, grenade mods, class mods -- there’s always something just a bit better, something you so desperately didn’t even know you needed until you found it in Borderlands 2. Just like other action RPGs, the hunt for loot becomes intoxicating because of the tiny rush you get each time a rare colored item spills out of a chest or recetly slain enemy. Guns are a bulk of the loot, and that’s great because you’re going to spend most of your time in Borderlands 2 staring down a gun sight.You simply have to decide the best -- or most entertaining -- way to kill everyone. Borderlands 2 is a much needed improvements to areas like narrative and class skill design to Borderlands. Overall this is an amazing shooter no one even remotely curious should overlook.

Grab your friends, give them shootalots and get into da choppa... or atleast bandit roadrunner.Having played Borderlands 1 over and over, then jumping onto Borderlands 2 expecting the same mayhem of flying bullets and screaming psychos, I definetely found what I looked for and expected from second installment. Game reintroduces our old Vault Hunters from previous game as NPCs with the feel of nostalgia, we get to play 4 new base heroes with simmiliar mechanics to old ones and introduces two more heroes with brand new mechanics which were made with support and feedback of fanbase since we all were trigger happy in Borderlands 1. We are carried through planet Pandora once again to show us what changed in meantime, then we get to know more and more of Handsome Jack, one of best developed villains of all times (next to Vaas from Far Cry 3). During game we get to shoot out all our happiness, frustration, we laugh a lot and sometimes feel sad, all because of very good made story, which rarely happens in shooter games nowadays.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2014
												Borderlands 2 (BL2) is the only game I’ve ever preordered, and I definitely understand why people say Game of the Year editions punish loyal customers and early buyers. The game is amazing but if I want to get the DLC, I’ll have to spend more than the actual game costs! I guess I’ll have to wait until the GOTY edition is really cheap and upgrade my game.BL2 is a first person shooter where you play as one of 4 (6 if you have the DLC) Vault Hunters on the planet Pandora. The story takes place sometime after the events of Borderlands 1 (maybe a few years) and quite a few characters from the first game show up in BL2. The game is world is very large and exploring everything is an exhausting but worthwhile job. You can learn a lot about the game by listening to hidden audio recordings or talking with NPCs. There’s quite a lot of humor in the game so it’s never dull. The boss especially, Handsome Jack, has tons of insults and stories to throw your way.As for gameplay, BL2 has a level system so I guess you could call it an RPG. Each level you get a skill point to put into 1 of about 45 different skills depending on your character. You can re-spec your skills at any time so you really only need 1 of each class to experience all the play styles. There are a few vehicles that you can drive depending on what area you’re in (travel can take forever if you’re on foot). BL2 has built in multiplayer so your friends can drop in or out at any time. Just like in the first game, if you’re “killed” you have about 5 seconds to Fight For Your Life. Kill any enemy during these 5 seconds and you’re revived. If you fail Fight For Your Life, you respawn at the nearest New-U kiosk (you don’t save or load the game manually). If you have a friend in the game, he can revive you during Fight For Your Life and you won’t have to respawn. Like the Diablo games, when you beat the game on normal mode, you can choose to replay on an increased difficulty level where both you and the enemies are higher level. Better gear will drop and almost all the enemies will gain resistances to various weapon types. This “True Vault Hunter Mode” gets insanely hard by the end of the game and you pretty much have to have a friend or 2 backing you up. BL2 is one of the few games that I’ve played through completely on coop with a friend and it definitely improves the experience.Overall I would definitely recommend Borderlands 2 to anyone who enjoys First Person Shooters or Action RPGs (I’ve got over 200 hours in this game). The story and combat are amazingly well done as is the humor and variety. However, definitely look for a “complete edition” since the Game of the Year edition actually doesn’t include all the DLC. I think Greenmangaming had a complete edition a week or so ago which included not only the Season Pass, but also both new characters and the Ultimate Vault Hunter upgrades (increasing the level cap and introducing new weapon types).

ry 10, 2015
												So far I love this box opening simulator. I played nearly 60 hours and I realize I barely played probably like only 5 percent of it. This game is huge in every aspect: missions, weapons, characters, DLCs, etc. And boxes. And chests. Loot everywhere. Literally everywhere.Also, I can fall from incredible heights and nothing happens to me.The well-written stories, the unique characters (some of the most charming and one-of-a-kind characters one could ever meet in a game), the omnipresent humor - these are just a few of the things that convinced me about this game. Not to mention I'm not even a fan of shooters, but the RPG elements of it, the stories, and all the other stuff compensate for that entirely.Did I say this game's got an incredible number of boxes /chests/ fridges/ barrels/ lockers/ filthy-water-closets/ other-lootable-stuff all over? You can't move in a straight line for 10 freaking meters without having to stop and open one of those, cause... you know... you may never know..

17, 2014
												Borderlands 2 takes game play mechanics from FPS like Halo and adds RPG elements of a game like Diablo. The game is very entertaining and can keep you playing for long periods of time. The story is average but the sense of humor makes up for it. Borderlands 2 has one of the most original visual styles of any game I have played in the last few years, with its concept art-style appearance and thick black lines evoking the look of a graphic novel.Bottom line: there is a reason  Borderlands 2 was one of the best selling games of 2012, and has become the best-selling game in the history of 2K Games.

content:
y 5
												This game is fantastic, though not without flaws. While this game maintains diversity in levels, weapons, and enemies, it really loses steam with the amount of grinding included in the game. Indeed, grinding is not inherintly bad, but it does become quite tedious and boring as the game stretches on. Also, some of the writing in this game is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible(cringy jokes, memes, and all round annoying cast members). However, the gameplay itself is fantastic, including so many skills and weapon types to the extent that finding a pretty gun with a new element consistantly never becomes stale. The art direction in this game is fantastic, as the cell shaded aesthetic really surprisingly clicks with the tone of the game. The vibrant colours and explosions succeed in creating eye candy for all to enjoy. In the end, I wholeheartedly reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys first person shooters, ARPGs, or any sort of coop-centric games.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
11, 2015
												While BioShock Infinite might be the best game I have ever played, Borderlands 2 is the absulutely best in terms of overall player experience. I have never ever had so much fun as when playing this game. Beautiful graphics, entertaining storyline, probably the best voice acting in all of video game industry, some of the greatest character designs ever made (Claptrap, Tiny Tina and especially Handsome Jack), immense amounts of loots (there are literally millions of guns you can choose from) and excellent replayability. The game has about 200 hours of gameplay if you wish to level a character entirely, which is a lot, but I guarantee you, they will be some of the best moments of your gaming life.A lot can be said about maturity of the content of the game as well. A lot of harsh language, sexual innuendos and things that would be disgusting in other games (cannibalism, torture and so on) is present, but the game is incredibly mature and deals with all of these themes in a very respectable way, which is further supplemented by the perfect graphics. Not only that, but the game also packs striking thoughts and supports LGBT rights, goes against domestic violence (I will never forget Mr. Torgue saying his best quote ever: "YOU BETTER TREAT MOXXI NICE! NOTHING IS MORE BADASS THAN TREATING A WOMAN WITH RESPECT!"), regards personal insecurity and many many other important topics in our current society. It does all of this with grace. There is even an NPC created specifically for a now-deceased Borderlands fan - and that is just one of many examples of how great the developers are. Honestly, Gearbox Software staff are some of the best people I have ever had the pleasure to meet.The humour in the game is also something that cannot be possibly overglorified. Not only you will find references to just about every game and pop culture theme ever to be made here, but the dialogues are incredibly funny even when discussing important things. The way the game makes fun of itself is something that absolutely captured me. ("Torgue weapons ALWAYS fire EXPLOSIVE ROUNDS. They are also LOUD and require EXCESSIVE use of CAPITAL LETTERS") The fourth wall is broken all the time, but it is done in a so incredibly funny way that it feels so, so right. ("Hey guys, remember the old Crawmerax the Invincible?" "Sure, we exploited his glitches for HOURS! Oh, Pearlescents!")The DLCs are all worth is as well, as they add a lot to the story and offer a lot additional content. Tiny Tina's Assault on the Dragon Keep is probably the greatest DLC ever created for any game ever. The amount of references, fun and interesting enemies present here are incredible. If I had to choose a single game out of all of them and spend the rest of my life playing it, it would be Borderlands 2.Would I recommend this game? No. No, I do not recommend you to buy this game. I recommend you to head to the Store and buy the Borderlands GOTY Edition, Borderlands 2 GOTY Edition, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel and it's Season Pass and The Tales of Borderlands as well. Buy the entire franchise. Just. Do. It. Also, write a love letter to Gearbox Software and thank them for creating the best game franchise currently to exist.

content:
r 10, 2015
												After having this game for a few years it's about time I write a review.Borderlands 2 is one of those games that seems to do everything right.Great story, amazing, diverse, interesting whacky characters and humour, so much to kill, quest and loot. Even the enemies are diverse and interesting. So many different kinds of enemies, from the large variety of bandits that say all manner of things when fighting you and the strange alien animal enemies such as skags, bullymongs and many others.No matter how many times I play this game I never get sick of it. Iam playing my third character and levelling her to max lvl and am still enjoying myself.The game also has RPG elements such as you have various skill trees to put points in as well as can customise the look of your character by skins and heads, though most of the more interesting ones you have to pay for.And you can try and do all the challenges if you do get bored which increases your badass rank, giving you tokens to put into increasing things like health, shield recharge rate etc. by a small .% of each token used, so it adds up and makes your character even stonger as you'll need it if you want to face terramorphous a very challenging lvl 52 super  boss.There is not really any major downsides I can think of with this game, had no bugs or problems, the controls are good.The only negatives I can think of is that I tend to out level quests, I end up lvl 19 and have a lvl 15 quest. And if you want the best loot you have to do a lot of boss farming.This game I'd class as almost perfect in my top 5 of all time favourite games. This is a must play game 9/10.

content:
24, 2014
													Well where to start.... GraphicsYes those visual friends of ours that tickle our eyes in jolly old delight.They are here in plenty tho a little dated the comic style in the way the game is presented is verynice. The lines colors and shades work well in this style and allow you "oooh and ahhh" at the screen as you fire away with one of your boom sticks.The next great thing in this game is loot and I mean LOOT every where. Its what its all about. after getting killed a few times and getting very frustrated with the game it pays of when you find some badd *** gun and take down the next few waves with an ear to ear grin plastered on your face.. AMAZING!Next is  co-opSeamless Co-Op. join a buddy's game and play on. Leaving body parts and gore in the tracks of your team. This is how co-op should be.Splitting money and a trade system between your groups allows no one to be left out of the loot bonanza! Next...mmmm what is next? Well the over all game play is fast paced and very addictive the game at times can seem a bit of a grind. Constant enemy waves put your poor trigger finger to the test and push the meaning of ammo conservation to the test. But then you find the loot bin and the grind had paid off, nicely too. The mission system shows how hard the next mission will be and if you need to roam around to level prior to your attempt is a great option.A level 4 taking on a level 6 mission will be very tough but levelling is easy in the beginning. After level five you get a skill point to spend in one of 3 trees to make your toon yours and yours alone. In my opinion this game sets a fast paced shooting callery of bandits, monsters, robots and other evil doing creatures. My advise is to lock load pre-pair your fingers and dive face first in the sea of bullets ahead and enjoy the visuals, game play and the company of a stark-raving mad friend to accompany you on this blissful murder feast.Enjoy!Graphics 8/10 Gameplay 8/10 Co-op 10/10 Controls 9/10 Content 9/10 Replay 7/10Overall 8.5 on the ~n00bz~ scale

												A frenetic and extremely funny cel-shaded FPS, mixed with some RPG elements and a fantastic random weapon system. Borderlands 2 is firstly a very well crafted shooter, with accurate mechanics and smooth, fast controls, which let you handle complex, long and exciting combats. Secondly, the environment and character design is wonderfully realized: the map is big and heterogeneous, while funny dialogues will make you laugh from the beginning to the end of the game. Main plot, secondary quests and amazing DLCs build a long-lasting game, never lowering the level of fun and challenge, especially in coop mode. Definitely one of the best FPS of the last years. 90/100I would also like to mention that italian dubbing is excellent, granting hilarious dialogues.

content:
6, 2015
REVIEW: BORDERLANDS 2: GAME OF THE YEAR EDITIONNote: I played this game solo.I’m generally not a major fan of FPSes. I’m more of an RPG sort of guy. And yet, I found myself interested and intrigued by the Borderlands series. When the series went on sale not long ago, I canvassed some friends’ opinions, whether I should get the first game, or the second. I had, admittedly, enjoyed watching the Two Saiyans Play videos of the latter. Having been told to get the second game, that’s what I did, getting the Game of the Year edition. But was it worth it? **** the hell, yeah!Five years have passed since the opening of the original Vault. The Hyperion Corporation, led by the egotistical and petulant tyrant Handsome Jack, has begun to tighten its grip on Pandora, killing bandits and the normal populace alike, all in the name of ‘taming’ the border world. As rumours of a new Vault spread, Jack makes the call for new Vault Hunters, only to kill them. But that was a mistake. A new group of Vault Hunters will rise, team up with old ones, and embark on a quest to stop Handsome Jack. But they have a hard task ahead of them, as Jack has more than one trump card up his sleeve…I enjoy games with a good story, and one thing that Borderlands does very well is the story. It’s like the mutant offspring of Mad Max and Red Dwarf, with a touch of Blake’s 7 (or Firefly, if you need a more modern show) thrown into the mix. Funny, full of references, and yet serious and full of pathos when it needs to, it’ll certainly have some shocks for fans of the first game. It’s also populated with a cast with the good, the bad, and the fugly. The storylines of the DLC ones are fine enough, though the real star storyline of the DLC campaigns is that of Tiny Tina’s Assault on Dragon Keep. It’s also one of those rare sequels that you can enjoy fully without any knowledge of the previous game.The graphics of the Borderlands series are very distinctive, being pseudo-cel shaded. They’re also pretty damned good, giving the right style and vibe to this world. There’s also a variety of landscapes, from desert and arid lands, to tundra, to cities, and even verdant mountains. The Borderlands series shows that realistic graphics aren’t always the way to go, that stylised graphics can often be better than the more realistic stuff some games seems to want to tend towards.Sound-wise, the game is superlative. The music is spot-on, albeit not as spectacular at times as I want it to be. The voice-acting, however, is something else, with particular praise going to Dameon Clarke as Handsome Jack, Cherami Leigh as Gaige, Jason Douglas as Krieg, Brina Palencia as Moxxi, Chris Rager as Torgue, Colleen Clinkenbeard as Lilith, Scarlett, and Tannis, David Eddings as Claptrap, and Ashly Burch as Tiny Tina. They, along with so many others, make this game wonderful, giving life to characters that make us laugh, cringe, and cry.But a game would be nothing without gameplay, and as far as FPSes are concerned, Borderlands 2 ****ing rocks. While I am not enticed by the series’ claims of ‘87 bazillion guns’, procedurally generated (though the elemental properties are certainly enjoyable), the hybridisation of an FPS and an RPG is considerably more interesting. Each character is given a unique attack ability or Action Skill, as well as a variety of abilities you can invest points in, RPG style, to customise your character’s abilities. The game itself can get a bit grindy at times, but thankfully, it’s one of the games that will have you having fun while doing so most of the time. The four DLC campaigns also add some substantial playtime to the game, and the two DLC characters are bloody good. Not only that, but it’s a game that you may very want to play through again, right from the beginning, which is why the True Vault Hunter mode may appeal to those who do want to do so.If you had to get one FPS to play in your entire life, then I would have to recommend Borderlands 2, hands-down. Get the Game of the Year edition. You won’t regret it.RATING: *****EDIT: Nominated this for the "Five More Minutes" Award for the Steam Awards 2016.

content:
2014
Borderlands 2 is one of the best games I have played, especially in recent history. There is very little to dislike about it: it has a great soundtrack, the cel shading art style is still gorgeous, it has the best sense of humor of any game (besides The Stanley Parable), the balance is really tight, a variety of playable characters to match any playstyle. and all of the loot and skill trees an RPG fan will love. Throw in co-op with friends, and I can't think of a better recipe for a good time. It's really a modern take on the Diablo series.One of the biggest complaints people had about the original Borderlands was that the story was nothing to write home about, and the end was a big disappointment. Gearbox very clearly went to great lengths to rectify this in Borderlands 2; they had a clear antagonist right from the beginning, and they did everything they could to make us hate his guts. I think they may have focused a little too much on this however, because there wasn't a whole lot else going on. The end boss was also really easy; it had a lot of health, but it dealt so little damage, I don't think my shields ever got depleted.Thankfully those are really the only complaints that I have about the game. Everything else was a big improvement over the original: more enemy variety, more interesting characters (the characters you played as in the original take center stage and get a lot more development than I was expecting). Even if I hadn't had my best friend to play with, I would have had a great time with Borderlands 2. I'd say that a reasonable price to pay is $40, but it's been around for so long you will most certainly pay less than that. We will soon be diving into the DLCs, so you'll be hearing about those soon enough.

content:
1, 2015
												Borderlands remains to this day my favorite game due to its uniqueness of combining rpg and fps elements with a great story and voice acting that were fun and entertained me for basically months of gameplay time, some of which isn't on Steam before I decided to buy the GOTY just so I could get all the achievements for this game. So don't get me wrong for the review below, but:I never hated jumping mechanics and invisible walls more than in this game, ever! Or map designs that make you cover a distance by going on an arch or a zig-zag to reach your objective just to add more gameplay time, and this happens especially in the dlcs. The first two aspects persist from the first game, but the third.. oh man. Also on that note I hated the most all the quests in Tundra Express given by Tiny Tina, because the entrance to her cave is located in exactly the opposite direction of all the objectives except one. I can't even remember how many times I've cursed the developers for making me run around a god damn rock to turn in something, just to get another in almost the same spot. Also the story is kinda forced and lacks character which made me quit the game two or three times before level 25 because I didn't connect with what was going on in it, and this is the first game I've pre-ordered! I still prefer the first Borderlands for that where you actually care about your hero and what's going on, you wanna get involved in changing the situation.Other than that it's still a great game built in the same manner with a lot of content that can keep you playing many hours alone or with friends and they did improve on the later part, connectivity becoming easily accesible which is great because that's why we're all using this Steam platform after all. So I can see why it lacks in some content, just to make up in other related to the multiplayer category, like the badass ranks and bonuses and all the playthroughs (hell in the first game max health and shields were in the two to four thousand limit), so the players have something to return to that doesn't feel absolete after just a few hours. I hope to see a Borderlands MMO one day, which seems they're getting closer and closer to and might be the perfect game yet as the developers usually listen to what the community asks for and they constantly improve the new releases on that matter.

												This game is really fun. With exciting AND addictive game-play that stays fresh even past the 10th play-through I am never bored with this game. The story is actually great and the superb voice acting makes it hard to not like the characters from the bandits to handsome Jack himself, on that the characters are well made and written and each is unique from the main cast (Zero, Maya, Axton and Salvador) to all the bosses, even to npc's such a Moxxi and Crazy Earl, each has a nice backstory from obtainable audio logs and also them talking to you through missions and just seeing them in generalThe humor plays a big part as well and is one of the main attractions of the Borderlands franchise but another is the graphics, the graphics look great overall and the PhysX makes it even better, the iconic graphics though not like Battlefield or Metro in quality are still amazing if you have a close look at the world in Borderlands 2, a change from Borderlands 1's post-apocalyptic landscape.The DLC are a must have, maybe not the skin packs so much but they are nice non-the-less, the real gems are the actual main DLC's, some are serious and to the campaign and some are crazy, each DLC is made around a character like Mr Torgue, the owner of the explosive guns but my favorite was the second to final boss, Professor Nakayama, (SPOILERS) He looks like he will mutate or something from the eridium markings but me and my friends were too busy laughing when he fell down the stairs and on each step he hit, his lifebar went down a chunk, easily one of the funniest moments in Borderlands (In my opinion)I had this on console and clocked litterally 1000's of hours on it, soon to be building a beast of a computer and will be returning to the Borderlands to have some fun and shoot some bandits in closing this game truly deserved Game of the Year and remains my favorite game of all time, it truely deserves this place and if anyone doesnt have this game you are missing out, it isnt everyones 'cup of tea' but for less that £5/$10 it is well worth it even if you arent a big fan and only play it once.NOTE: THIS IS QUITE BIASED AS I AM A HUGE FAN OF THE SERIES AND HAVE GOT A LOT MORE HOURS ON CONSOLEGraphics - 8/10Humour - 9/10Plot - 7/10Lifetime - 9/10Gameplay - 10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 10, 2015
												Gameplay: The shooting mechanics are very competent, although there is not as much differentiation between weapons as there was in the original Borderlands, the weapon variety is still much more impressive than most other games on the market (as of this review). The gunplay is designed to be fast paced, with each character having an equally high jump height and no fall damage. Unfortunately many of the available skills add little to the gameplay, only making minor changes to stats such as damage and reload speed (although there are a few instances in which a particular skill can radically change the way you play). Overall the shooting is fun, but can get repetitive over time. This is remedied by playing with friends, which spices up the general gameplay; but unfortunately repitition and lack of incentivising loot made the game a chore to play for me towards the end.Story: The plot is sullied by an annoying dichotomy between the game's attempts at creating forced emotion and a cheap laugh, moments of particular emotional weight are negated entirely when a sudden line or action from a character attempts to provide comic relief or simply emphasise the game's ludicrous nature; because of this it is hard to take the plot seriously and moments that would otherwise be genuinely funny are simply annoying or distracting. The game has moments which did make me laugh, but often resorts to borderline juvenile jokes, which compared to the few witty lines feel out of place and hamper the overall comedic experience. Graphics: The cell-shaded art style is certainly unique and works in tandem with the semi-realistic world of Pandora to create an environment that is both grounded in reality but also clearly fictional. This is to the game's benefit, immersing the player into the intruiging world without the need for particularly detailed models or textures (not to say that these are lacking, many of the weapons and locations are imbued with a unique style of their own, but as years go by the art style will not age as badly as those games which attempt to portray a pseudo-realistic world, but are limited by current technology).Sound: The soundtrack consists primarily of electronic music, which works in synonym with the fast-paced gameplay. The voice acting is well done as well, with many characters having well voiced dialogues. Sound design throughout the game is well done.Re-playability: There are four different classes, each with a unique special ability (being able to dual-weild weapons, deploy a turret, etc.), but the skills available to each of these classes are not particularly unique, so replaying the game is not especially worthwhile. There are a large amount of challenges, but many can be simply accomplished through normal gameplay, or are very grindy.tl;dr: Great game, but can get repetitive. More fun with friends.

content:
y 13, 2015
												Borderlands 2 is spot-on in every way. From the hilarious characters with brilliantly written dialogue to the enticing loot to the zany, phrenetic combat, every aspect of the game is perfectly executed. Gearbox took a risk in casting four (six) new vault hunters to replace those from the original Borderlands, but the new characters fill in their positions excellently. In addition, Lilith, Mordecai, Brick and Roland all play major parts in the game as NPCs, and their presence is welcome. Claptrap returns as well, as humorously moronic as before. The four new vault hunters, Axton (Commando), Zer0 (Assassin), Salvador (Gunzerker), and Maya (Siren), are racing against Handsome Jack, president of the Hyperion Corporation, to reach and open a new vault. In addition to the main four vault hunters, there are two DLC characters, Gaige the Mechromancer and KRIEG the Psycho, who are definitely worth purchasing if you are into the game. They are included in the Game of the Year Edition. The story is entertaining throughout, with plenty of fun side missions to complete if and when you finish the main game. There are also three DLC bonus campaigns which are all extremely fun. In conclusion, Borderlands 2 is a rare 10/10 in my book. It's one of those games that is just plain old fun, without sacrificing a clever, well thought-out story and excellent character design.

content:
8, 2014
												This game is brilliant. There's no other way of putting it. This game is fun in single player, and super-fun in co-op.Gameplay:- There is nothing more satisfying in perhaps any other game than seeing a stream of CRITICAL damage indicators streaming off a psycopath/midget/fat person/robot's head.- The variety in guns, grenade mods and shields is unprecedented. In co-op, you'll constantly be comparing your gear to that of your friends, trying out their weapons, trading weapons. All of the gun types are fun to use - especially revolvers. I swear they're magical or something...- The game is a well-made hybrid of FPS and RPG. You can give your character (one of 4 classes in the base game, with 2 more in the GOTY edition) abilities and level them up, enabling you to use better weapons, grenade mods and shield. Story:- Ridiculous humour that works - that about sums it up. You'll encounter crazy situations and missions, but you'll just accept it.- There's an awful lot of it. The main story missions don't often feel recycled, presenting you with different challenges every time. There's plenty of voice acting in both the main campaign and side quests, whcih is impressive considering the volume of these.- There are a fair few unexpected plot twists, but it usually doesn't feel dragged out.- Handsome Jack is both formidable and funny. He's a truly worthy nemesis.- Claptrap makes you want to kill him within 20 seconds of meeting him. I've yet to hear a voice on par with how annoying Claptrap's is.Graphics and Sound:- If you crank the settings up, this game looks pretty nice. The cartoony style means it also runs well on lower-end PCs without looking muddy.- If you have an NVIDIA card, you're in for a treat. There are cloth and liquid PhysX, and you can cut the cloth with bullets. Debris flies off the environment and bounces off things. It makes hectic situations look awesome.- Gun sounds and voice acting are great, everything else is generally OK, not too special.- I've had a couple of unexpected slowdowns and 2-second freezes. This shouldn't happen on my PC really, but I suspect it's PhysX related. I keep PhysX on Medium or High, though, because it's great.Multiplayer:- The game has 2-4 player co-op multiplayer. All missions work in both single-player and co-op, with enemy volume and health scaling to keep difficulty constant.- You can start duels for loot with your fellow players, in the event of disagreement.- Pretty seamless. Invite players to your game from the main menu, and they drop into your world with all your mission progression.- I'd advise that everyone has a different class, otherwise you'll all die at the same time and respawn back at a checkpoint, which gets annoying.- For best experience, everyone in your co-op session should be within about a 10-level range of each other, or the underlevelled character will need reviving constantly.Summary:This game should be compulsory. My life is complete, now that I can shoot midgets with shotguns and find cool loot in portaloos. My advice: buy GOTY - you'll want all the Borderlands you can get.

content:
er 28, 2013
												I started up Borderlands 2 thinking this game would be an average shooter with a crappy story. I had played only a small portion of the original Borderlands. A warning before you buy, the introduction to this game can be boring, but once you start leveling up, spending skill points and gaining unique loot, the game truely starts. As I followed my new 'friend' Claptrap, throughout the world of Pandora I started to realize what a marvel this game truely was. I met new characters. laughed my ♥♥♥ off and starting gaining allies. Handsome Jack, the antagonist, seemed to make me laugh more than anyone else. I thought this game was only goofy and comedic, especially when I met Tiny Tina. As I got to know characters I started to get atttached, although that was a mistake. Epic battles and heart wrenching experiences ensued. This game is definetly an emotional rollercoaster. Besides the story missions there is tons of side missions, but unlike most side missions in other games. Instead of an average side mission, like 'Collect 25 Flowers' or 'Kill 25 Enemies' each side mission contains its own story. Whether it be competely humorous or extremely depressing and sad, every side mission was unique in its own way. Another fantastic thing this game is the amount of loot and different weapons. According to Gearbox software (the game developer) there are over 17 million different guns in this game. If you finish all of the side missions and story missions, the game is constantly being given new DLCs (Downloadable Content) containing tons of missions and hilarious campaigns. If you are looking for tons of fun either by yourself or with friends, Borderlands 2 is for you.

content:
y 13, 2015
												Borderlands 2 is spot-on in every way. From the hilarious characters with brilliantly written dialogue to the enticing loot to the zany, phrenetic combat, every aspect of the game is perfectly executed. Gearbox took a risk in casting four (six) new vault hunters to replace those from the original Borderlands, but the new characters fill in their positions excellently. In addition, Lilith, Mordecai, Brick and Roland all play major parts in the game as NPCs, and their presence is welcome. Claptrap returns as well, as humorously moronic as before. The four new vault hunters, Axton (Commando), Zer0 (Assassin), Salvador (Gunzerker), and Maya (Siren), are racing against Handsome Jack, president of the Hyperion Corporation, to reach and open a new vault. In addition to the main four vault hunters, there are two DLC characters, Gaige the Mechromancer and KRIEG the Psycho, who are definitely worth purchasing if you are into the game. They are included in the Game of the Year Edition. The story is entertaining throughout, with plenty of fun side missions to complete if and when you finish the main game. There are also three DLC bonus campaigns which are all extremely fun. In conclusion, Borderlands 2 is a rare 10/10 in my book. It's one of those games that is just plain old fun, without sacrificing a clever, well thought-out story and excellent character design.

y 9, 2014
												Borderlands 2. Those who like it love it, those who hate it always will. Nonetheless, I'm one of those who loves it. I myself have played well over 300 hours of this game across different platforms, and have at least 9 separate characters. The game-play is fluid, easy to jump into, and immensely fun. The amount of enemies spanning from humans, to robots, to crazy ♥♥♥ creatures is immense, and the amount only increases with the second and third play-throughs. And obviously, Borderlands 2's procedural weapon system, with the 12 bazillion guns, is a lot of fun. You never know what you're gonna get. And the DLC's amazingly add even more of these great things into the game, along with more of the hilarious humor that you quickly come to love. Overall, this game is easily in my top three of all time favourites, and might just be up there as #1. I'd recommend it to anybody who likes grinding for levels and loot, and somebody who has a sense of humor.

content:
er 17, 2013
												I have unregretfully poured just a little over 400hrs into this game. It's been nothing short of amazing and definitely ranks amongst the Top 5 this generation. The gameplay, story, drop system and dialogue are MASSIVE (and I'm not exaggerating) improvements over the first game. The main quest doesn't feel as tedious, bland and empty as BL1, in which some will give you the chance to earn slight bonuses, consisting of stronger weapons, shields or even character skins. One of the major overhauls I love the most is the Badass Rank. Completing levels of challenges will increase your BA Rank and give you a token whi you can apply to stat increase for better accuracy, longer duration of DoT effects (shock, fire, corrosive) or overall damage. And your BA Rank is applied to all characters that you create (my BA Rank is around 31,000 or so) so you can start off a new character and be extremely overpowered but in the long run it will pay off as True Vault Hunter Mode will greatly amp up the difficulty. More so with Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode (not recommended until Lv61 because of level scaling). You can also earn skins from these challenges as well.Of the core classes available you have Axton the commando, whose Sabre Turret shreds up everything when deployed. Going down specific trees allows the turret to fire rockets, set of a radial nuke or even grant the ability to deploy 2 at once. Maya is a Siren, much like Lilith but instead of Phase Shifting for an advantage, she can use Phase Lock. Phase Lock surrounds the target in a orb when invested into skills like Elated, Sweet Release, Helios and Chain Reaction, you'll set the enemy on fire, drain health (and restore it to your friends) and transfer that orb to the next target. Gaige the Mechomancer (who was available as a preorder bonus before the game launched) has Deathtrap. Deathtrap is basically your scout who'll rip apart anything in sight and his abilities are further amplified when going down the Best Friends Forever tree. I've invested a few points into BFF myself but I'm more partial to Little Big Trouble. LBT primarily focuses on Shock damage, in which some weapons (and shields) can make Gaige literally invincible. There's much more I can say here but I'll wrap this up with: If you see it on sale, better yet the GOTY Edition which includes all of the DLC (not the paid skins) you are definitely getting a huge bang for your buck. 10/10.

content:
2014
Borderlands 2 is one of the best games I have played, especially in recent history. There is very little to dislike about it: it has a great soundtrack, the cel shading art style is still gorgeous, it has the best sense of humor of any game (besides The Stanley Parable), the balance is really tight, a variety of playable characters to match any playstyle. and all of the loot and skill trees an RPG fan will love. Throw in co-op with friends, and I can't think of a better recipe for a good time. It's really a modern take on the Diablo series.One of the biggest complaints people had about the original Borderlands was that the story was nothing to write home about, and the end was a big disappointment. Gearbox very clearly went to great lengths to rectify this in Borderlands 2; they had a clear antagonist right from the beginning, and they did everything they could to make us hate his guts. I think they may have focused a little too much on this however, because there wasn't a whole lot else going on. The end boss was also really easy; it had a lot of health, but it dealt so little damage, I don't think my shields ever got depleted.Thankfully those are really the only complaints that I have about the game. Everything else was a big improvement over the original: more enemy variety, more interesting characters (the characters you played as in the original take center stage and get a lot more development than I was expecting). Even if I hadn't had my best friend to play with, I would have had a great time with Borderlands 2. I'd say that a reasonable price to pay is $40, but it's been around for so long you will most certainly pay less than that. We will soon be diving into the DLCs, so you'll be hearing about those soon enough.

content:
ber 12, 2014
												Trust me when I say that trying to rate a favourite game and remain open for the contras of the game is really hard.Short review: Loot’n’Shoot, Shoot’n’Loot.Long review:I bought this game for one reason only – my friends bought it and I would have been bored to play anything else on my own. Prior to playing it, I didn’t like the typical cartoonish style and wasn’t really excited about the option to remove the thick border lines either.So I bought it, installed it and started playing with my friends – I still wasn’t very excited about the game – but maybe because the first few missions aren’t very captivating. But a bit further in the playthrough and a few level-ups later…. BOOM! I fell in love! I obsessed with the characters, storyline and loved the dialogues. All I wanted to do in my spare time was playing BL2! At a certain amount of characters and playthroughs, I stopped playing. And when I decided to play a bit again, I remembered the love…DLCs:I have all the playable DLCs and enjoyed them all. If you liked it and don’t have a budget to buy all the DLCs, then I believe you should definitely get ‘Borderlands 2: Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep’ and ‘Borderlands 2: Mr. Torgue’s Campaign of Carnage’.The mini DLCs are really really short (Headhunter 1: Bloody Harvest; Headhunter 2: Wattle Gobbler; Headhunter 3: Mercenary Day; Headhunter 4: Wedding Day Massacre; Headhunter 5: Son of Crawmerax;). On the other hand you get to do fun stuff like *SPOILERS!*  drinking whiskey, making babies cry, kill happy loving couples, kill drunk enemies and chase loot leprechauns…Contras:The only thing I can point out here is what happened to me when me and my friends. What happened to me is that me and my friends started new characters to play together, but of them didn’t play as much as the others. This lead to a huge difference in levels and the low level character being useless and unable to enjoy the game. Of course, there are ways to work around this and this is isn’t a flaw in the game itself. Nevertheless, I do believe this still should be said, as BL2 is not like Dead Island, where all characters can be different levels and can still play together (due to level compensation).Deathtrap is quite buggy when you’re in the menu: 


Good boy :) 
A Screenshot of Borderlands 2
By: Ho Lee Fuk




It’s not much of a big deal IMO, but you might get to see a few of these when loading a new location - 


Best map EVER!!!!! 
A Screenshot of Borderlands 2
By: Ho Lee Fuk




Pros:I like the graphics, even though I can’t play on the maxed out settings or with PhysX on high quality. Having the graphics settings on max looks awesome though (as per my knowledge there are a few bugs showing on the highest settings).Finding and joining someone else’s game is easy and straight forward and the community is awesome – if you ask, you’ll be helped by complete strangers. As I prefer coop games, this made my gaming experience really enjoyable. It should be noted that, as BL2 is a coop game, there shouldn’t be any reason for players not to be nice, but still… Nice people become more an exception in real life and on the internet, so I have to point this out.What I love is the dialogues, the NPCs response when you engage in talking with them (check screens in the bottom, but beware –  SPOILERS!), the characters’ story and custom dialogues depending on the character you play (in the mini DLC’s).For me, the biggest ‘pro’ for BL2 is the fact that it made me laugh so hard, so many times. If anything can make you laugh and cry at the same time, then it’s worth spending the time. Of course, humour varies, so it can’t be a guaranteed fun time for everyone.Will you like the game or not? I don’t know… It really depends on what you expect and like, so make your choice.Screenshots = Spoilers!NPC dialogue lines:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=234047759http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=234047391http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=165472838http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=234047552Typical BL2 humour:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=155631698http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=180275753http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=231877045http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=205405674

content:
7, 2014
												Let me lay it down for you guys, Borderlands 2 is one of my new favorite games in my library. Borderlands 2 is a hybrid FPS RPG 4 player Co-Op game. Now, when I say RPG, I don't mean something like Final Fantasy, Skyrim, or Dragon Age. Those games need you to be fully invested in the RPG elements of the game, and while I do like that sometimes, other times it gets boring for me. Borderlands 2's system feels very unobtrusive and can produce some good results even if you are randomly picking things in the skill tree. But if you do put some thought into your character's skills and how you play the game, you could be rewarded with a character that is perfect just for you. A good thing to mention is that there is only 4 (now 6 with DLC) classes to choose. While that doesn't seem like many to some people, each charcter is unique in skillset and apperance. I must say, even though it didn't feel like then, the first 1 to 2 hours are slow. You don't even unlock skills untill lvl 5. That goes away once you hit the "hub" city of Sanctuary. This is where the story picks up and the one of my favorite parts of the game shines, the side quests. These missions never take themselves too seriously and sometimes are quite inventive, more than the standard fetch quests other games make you do. And everyonce in a while you start a quest that turns into a large chain of quests, building this little mini story (A good example of this is Ellie's Clan War quest). The main story is okay, much better than the orignial's, but it isn't close to the amount of depth some other shooters have. However the writing is great and is very funny. All of the NPCs have their own personality and some you can really begin to love after a while. Except Claptrap. I can love him in short bursts.For the FPS element, it comes down to the guns. Remember when I said the RPG system was unobtrusive? I kinda lied, as I have spent lots of time just sitting and comparing the stats of guns, shields, class mods, relics, and grenades to each other. Guns can be pistols, shotguns, assault rifles, snipers, SMGs, and rocket launchers. All equipment has a manufacturer which decides for guns what it's strenght has. So Jacobs guns are usually high damage, low capcity, semi-auto guns, but the fire as fast as you can pull the trigger. Hyperion guns actually get more accurate the more shots the fire. And there are more brands with more effects. Then there is elemental types that do more damage to certain types of enemies, like fire doing more damge to biological enemies, corriosive doing more to armored enemies, ect. So when ever you pick up a gun you have a lot of things to consider.Speaking of guns and loot there is a serious issue when it come to Co-Op. When an enemy drops a gun, it only drops one. Not a problem in single player. But with 4 people that causes issues, especially on bosses who drop really valuable loot. For me that is my only serious issue with the game, and I play by myself mostly anyway.I've had lot's of fun playing this game, and if you don't own it, I suggest you do. I also suggest you get the Game of the Year edition which is a great value. And remember in the words of Markus the gunsalesman, "No Refunds!"

content:
ber 20, 2016
												I have been an avid fan of the Borderlands series since I first played the original installment back in 2008. Below is my personal impression of its pros and cons:Pros: + Engaging, immersive gameplay. + Fun and worthwhile cooperative multiplayer experience. + Graphics and art-style is timeless, aging through the generations remarkably well. + Creative characters, both playable and NPC. + Great level design and set-dressing. There are lots of little details to find and explore. + Detailed universe, with a captivating storyline that further motivates you to keep playing. + Great gameplay balance with the leveling system, making progress feel rewarding. + Varied characters with a range of possible play-styles. + Excellent compatibility in terms of your computer's performance. Even low-end computers with generic graphic cards can comfortably play (with reasonable quality adjustments). + LOADS of extremely entertaining and creative DLC to play after you've finished the main story. DLC campaigns are also fairly priced. + Tiny Tina. + Meat Bicycles.Cons: - No evident compensation for high latency in network play. - No in-game method to view your ping. I often try judging my latency by how long it takes a bullet to leave my gun after firing. - There's an anticlimax once a character has reached the highest possible experience level. Each subsequent kill and other progress after that, comes accross as less rewarding. - A character becomes progressively more difficult to fully level up. Less experienced FPS players will likely find the tougher play-through modes more frustrating than fun. Playing with friends, especially in True Vault Hunter Mode or Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode is definitely recommended. - Relatively predictable storyline for the main campaign, but still worthwhile.Ultimately, I fully recommend this game, as well as the other titles in the series, despite their shortcomings. It's an experience I always look forward to, whether I get to play with friends, or when I just wing it solo. There's a unique joy in finding that occasional super-rare item, or popping the head off a cheeky psycho that wants to be buried upside-down!

content:
6, 2015
REVIEW: BORDERLANDS 2: GAME OF THE YEAR EDITIONNote: I played this game solo.I’m generally not a major fan of FPSes. I’m more of an RPG sort of guy. And yet, I found myself interested and intrigued by the Borderlands series. When the series went on sale not long ago, I canvassed some friends’ opinions, whether I should get the first game, or the second. I had, admittedly, enjoyed watching the Two Saiyans Play videos of the latter. Having been told to get the second game, that’s what I did, getting the Game of the Year edition. But was it worth it? **** the hell, yeah!Five years have passed since the opening of the original Vault. The Hyperion Corporation, led by the egotistical and petulant tyrant Handsome Jack, has begun to tighten its grip on Pandora, killing bandits and the normal populace alike, all in the name of ‘taming’ the border world. As rumours of a new Vault spread, Jack makes the call for new Vault Hunters, only to kill them. But that was a mistake. A new group of Vault Hunters will rise, team up with old ones, and embark on a quest to stop Handsome Jack. But they have a hard task ahead of them, as Jack has more than one trump card up his sleeve…I enjoy games with a good story, and one thing that Borderlands does very well is the story. It’s like the mutant offspring of Mad Max and Red Dwarf, with a touch of Blake’s 7 (or Firefly, if you need a more modern show) thrown into the mix. Funny, full of references, and yet serious and full of pathos when it needs to, it’ll certainly have some shocks for fans of the first game. It’s also populated with a cast with the good, the bad, and the fugly. The storylines of the DLC ones are fine enough, though the real star storyline of the DLC campaigns is that of Tiny Tina’s Assault on Dragon Keep. It’s also one of those rare sequels that you can enjoy fully without any knowledge of the previous game.The graphics of the Borderlands series are very distinctive, being pseudo-cel shaded. They’re also pretty damned good, giving the right style and vibe to this world. There’s also a variety of landscapes, from desert and arid lands, to tundra, to cities, and even verdant mountains. The Borderlands series shows that realistic graphics aren’t always the way to go, that stylised graphics can often be better than the more realistic stuff some games seems to want to tend towards.Sound-wise, the game is superlative. The music is spot-on, albeit not as spectacular at times as I want it to be. The voice-acting, however, is something else, with particular praise going to Dameon Clarke as Handsome Jack, Cherami Leigh as Gaige, Jason Douglas as Krieg, Brina Palencia as Moxxi, Chris Rager as Torgue, Colleen Clinkenbeard as Lilith, Scarlett, and Tannis, David Eddings as Claptrap, and Ashly Burch as Tiny Tina. They, along with so many others, make this game wonderful, giving life to characters that make us laugh, cringe, and cry.But a game would be nothing without gameplay, and as far as FPSes are concerned, Borderlands 2 ****ing rocks. While I am not enticed by the series’ claims of ‘87 bazillion guns’, procedurally generated (though the elemental properties are certainly enjoyable), the hybridisation of an FPS and an RPG is considerably more interesting. Each character is given a unique attack ability or Action Skill, as well as a variety of abilities you can invest points in, RPG style, to customise your character’s abilities. The game itself can get a bit grindy at times, but thankfully, it’s one of the games that will have you having fun while doing so most of the time. The four DLC campaigns also add some substantial playtime to the game, and the two DLC characters are bloody good. Not only that, but it’s a game that you may very want to play through again, right from the beginning, which is why the True Vault Hunter mode may appeal to those who do want to do so.If you had to get one FPS to play in your entire life, then I would have to recommend Borderlands 2, hands-down. Get the Game of the Year edition. You won’t regret it.RATING: *****EDIT: Nominated this for the "Five More Minutes" Award for the Steam Awards 2016.

y 3, 2014
												This game is really fun. With exciting AND addictive game-play that stays fresh even past the 10th play-through I am never bored with this game. The story is actually great and the superb voice acting makes it hard to not like the characters from the bandits to handsome Jack himself, on that the characters are well made and written and each is unique from the main cast (Zero, Maya, Axton and Salvador) to all the bosses, even to npc's such a Moxxi and Crazy Earl, each has a nice backstory from obtainable audio logs and also them talking to you through missions and just seeing them in generalThe humor plays a big part as well and is one of the main attractions of the Borderlands franchise but another is the graphics, the graphics look great overall and the PhysX makes it even better, the iconic graphics though not like Battlefield or Metro in quality are still amazing if you have a close look at the world in Borderlands 2, a change from Borderlands 1's post-apocalyptic landscape.The DLC are a must have, maybe not the skin packs so much but they are nice non-the-less, the real gems are the actual main DLC's, some are serious and to the campaign and some are crazy, each DLC is made around a character like Mr Torgue, the owner of the explosive guns but my favorite was the second to final boss, Professor Nakayama, (SPOILERS) He looks like he will mutate or something from the eridium markings but me and my friends were too busy laughing when he fell down the stairs and on each step he hit, his lifebar went down a chunk, easily one of the funniest moments in Borderlands (In my opinion)I had this on console and clocked litterally 1000's of hours on it, soon to be building a beast of a computer and will be returning to the Borderlands to have some fun and shoot some bandits in closing this game truly deserved Game of the Year and remains my favorite game of all time, it truely deserves this place and if anyone doesnt have this game you are missing out, it isnt everyones 'cup of tea' but for less that £5/$10 it is well worth it even if you arent a big fan and only play it once.NOTE: THIS IS QUITE BIASED AS I AM A HUGE FAN OF THE SERIES AND HAVE GOT A LOT MORE HOURS ON CONSOLEGraphics - 8/10Humour - 9/10Plot - 7/10Lifetime - 9/10Gameplay - 10/10

content:
er 17, 2013
												I have unregretfully poured just a little over 400hrs into this game. It's been nothing short of amazing and definitely ranks amongst the Top 5 this generation. The gameplay, story, drop system and dialogue are MASSIVE (and I'm not exaggerating) improvements over the first game. The main quest doesn't feel as tedious, bland and empty as BL1, in which some will give you the chance to earn slight bonuses, consisting of stronger weapons, shields or even character skins. One of the major overhauls I love the most is the Badass Rank. Completing levels of challenges will increase your BA Rank and give you a token whi you can apply to stat increase for better accuracy, longer duration of DoT effects (shock, fire, corrosive) or overall damage. And your BA Rank is applied to all characters that you create (my BA Rank is around 31,000 or so) so you can start off a new character and be extremely overpowered but in the long run it will pay off as True Vault Hunter Mode will greatly amp up the difficulty. More so with Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode (not recommended until Lv61 because of level scaling). You can also earn skins from these challenges as well.Of the core classes available you have Axton the commando, whose Sabre Turret shreds up everything when deployed. Going down specific trees allows the turret to fire rockets, set of a radial nuke or even grant the ability to deploy 2 at once. Maya is a Siren, much like Lilith but instead of Phase Shifting for an advantage, she can use Phase Lock. Phase Lock surrounds the target in a orb when invested into skills like Elated, Sweet Release, Helios and Chain Reaction, you'll set the enemy on fire, drain health (and restore it to your friends) and transfer that orb to the next target. Gaige the Mechomancer (who was available as a preorder bonus before the game launched) has Deathtrap. Deathtrap is basically your scout who'll rip apart anything in sight and his abilities are further amplified when going down the Best Friends Forever tree. I've invested a few points into BFF myself but I'm more partial to Little Big Trouble. LBT primarily focuses on Shock damage, in which some weapons (and shields) can make Gaige literally invincible. There's much more I can say here but I'll wrap this up with: If you see it on sale, better yet the GOTY Edition which includes all of the DLC (not the paid skins) you are definitely getting a huge bang for your buck. 10/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 10, 2015
												Gameplay: The shooting mechanics are very competent, although there is not as much differentiation between weapons as there was in the original Borderlands, the weapon variety is still much more impressive than most other games on the market (as of this review). The gunplay is designed to be fast paced, with each character having an equally high jump height and no fall damage. Unfortunately many of the available skills add little to the gameplay, only making minor changes to stats such as damage and reload speed (although there are a few instances in which a particular skill can radically change the way you play). Overall the shooting is fun, but can get repetitive over time. This is remedied by playing with friends, which spices up the general gameplay; but unfortunately repitition and lack of incentivising loot made the game a chore to play for me towards the end.Story: The plot is sullied by an annoying dichotomy between the game's attempts at creating forced emotion and a cheap laugh, moments of particular emotional weight are negated entirely when a sudden line or action from a character attempts to provide comic relief or simply emphasise the game's ludicrous nature; because of this it is hard to take the plot seriously and moments that would otherwise be genuinely funny are simply annoying or distracting. The game has moments which did make me laugh, but often resorts to borderline juvenile jokes, which compared to the few witty lines feel out of place and hamper the overall comedic experience. Graphics: The cell-shaded art style is certainly unique and works in tandem with the semi-realistic world of Pandora to create an environment that is both grounded in reality but also clearly fictional. This is to the game's benefit, immersing the player into the intruiging world without the need for particularly detailed models or textures (not to say that these are lacking, many of the weapons and locations are imbued with a unique style of their own, but as years go by the art style will not age as badly as those games which attempt to portray a pseudo-realistic world, but are limited by current technology).Sound: The soundtrack consists primarily of electronic music, which works in synonym with the fast-paced gameplay. The voice acting is well done as well, with many characters having well voiced dialogues. Sound design throughout the game is well done.Re-playability: There are four different classes, each with a unique special ability (being able to dual-weild weapons, deploy a turret, etc.), but the skills available to each of these classes are not particularly unique, so replaying the game is not especially worthwhile. There are a large amount of challenges, but many can be simply accomplished through normal gameplay, or are very grindy.tl;dr: Great game, but can get repetitive. More fun with friends.

content:
y 13, 2015
												Borderlands 2 is spot-on in every way. From the hilarious characters with brilliantly written dialogue to the enticing loot to the zany, phrenetic combat, every aspect of the game is perfectly executed. Gearbox took a risk in casting four (six) new vault hunters to replace those from the original Borderlands, but the new characters fill in their positions excellently. In addition, Lilith, Mordecai, Brick and Roland all play major parts in the game as NPCs, and their presence is welcome. Claptrap returns as well, as humorously moronic as before. The four new vault hunters, Axton (Commando), Zer0 (Assassin), Salvador (Gunzerker), and Maya (Siren), are racing against Handsome Jack, president of the Hyperion Corporation, to reach and open a new vault. In addition to the main four vault hunters, there are two DLC characters, Gaige the Mechromancer and KRIEG the Psycho, who are definitely worth purchasing if you are into the game. They are included in the Game of the Year Edition. The story is entertaining throughout, with plenty of fun side missions to complete if and when you finish the main game. There are also three DLC bonus campaigns which are all extremely fun. In conclusion, Borderlands 2 is a rare 10/10 in my book. It's one of those games that is just plain old fun, without sacrificing a clever, well thought-out story and excellent character design.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												Saying I love this game is an understatement. I could play this game and never tire of it, and it's that kind of endless re-playability that makes Borderlands 2 one of the best buying decisions you'll ever make. A word of warning though: make sure you have at least one friend to play it with. Multiplayer is what truly makes this game worth playing every single day. Sure, playing the campaigns solo is fun and satisfying on its own, but with a friend (or friends) the game takes on a whole new dimension of enjoyment. I love every bit of dialogue in this game, the writing is spot-on hilarious, and even emotionally touching at times. And the weapons....oh, the weapons~    Searching for rare, legendary or otherwise badass weaponry is a reason to play in and of itself. It seems the possibilites in this world are truly endless. It's an action FPS on the outside, sure, but I love just how much of an adventure RPG-element there is at the heart of the game in terms of style and character skill development. You care about the characters plights, as well as the story itself. Borderlands 2 really has its own personality, and you can immerse yourself completely in this crazy world. Another thing to mention is the DLC. There are plenty of extra missions to choose from, and it only adds to the replay value. In fact, you're much better off just buying the Game of the Year edition since it includes a lot of them.  Since I mentioned RPG's earlier, I will specifically suggest Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep as my favorite of all the DLC missions. If you enjoy Magic the Gathering, Final Fantasy, Dungeons and Dragons or anything like it---you will experience a nerdgasm with this one.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2015
												Borderlands remains to this day my favorite game due to its uniqueness of combining rpg and fps elements with a great story and voice acting that were fun and entertained me for basically months of gameplay time, some of which isn't on Steam before I decided to buy the GOTY just so I could get all the achievements for this game. So don't get me wrong for the review below, but:I never hated jumping mechanics and invisible walls more than in this game, ever! Or map designs that make you cover a distance by going on an arch or a zig-zag to reach your objective just to add more gameplay time, and this happens especially in the dlcs. The first two aspects persist from the first game, but the third.. oh man. Also on that note I hated the most all the quests in Tundra Express given by Tiny Tina, because the entrance to her cave is located in exactly the opposite direction of all the objectives except one. I can't even remember how many times I've cursed the developers for making me run around a god damn rock to turn in something, just to get another in almost the same spot. Also the story is kinda forced and lacks character which made me quit the game two or three times before level 25 because I didn't connect with what was going on in it, and this is the first game I've pre-ordered! I still prefer the first Borderlands for that where you actually care about your hero and what's going on, you wanna get involved in changing the situation.Other than that it's still a great game built in the same manner with a lot of content that can keep you playing many hours alone or with friends and they did improve on the later part, connectivity becoming easily accesible which is great because that's why we're all using this Steam platform after all. So I can see why it lacks in some content, just to make up in other related to the multiplayer category, like the badass ranks and bonuses and all the playthroughs (hell in the first game max health and shields were in the two to four thousand limit), so the players have something to return to that doesn't feel absolete after just a few hours. I hope to see a Borderlands MMO one day, which seems they're getting closer and closer to and might be the perfect game yet as the developers usually listen to what the community asks for and they constantly improve the new releases on that matter.

												Borderlands 2 is (obviously) a sequel to Borderlands, set on the world of Pandora, where you, a vaulthunter, have to take it up against Hyperion and their leader which is also your nemesis: Handsome Jack.PROS:+ Enormous amount of gameplay (can vary between 50-200+ hours with different characters and DLC)+ Multiple characters to play with, each with their own special ability and skill tree+ Giant library of highly creative weapons+ Has multiple stories and sidestories+ Upgradable by various DLC's+ Many places to go and many enemies to fight+ Looting is incredibly fun+ Many funny dialogues, jokes and charactersCONS:- A lot of ingame items require additional payment- The weapons often feel a little unsatisfying in terms of physics and sound- You die a lot, and if you die in certain areas, you have fight through the entire area again, including walking all the wayBoth the type of gamers looking for action as well as gamers looking for a game rich in story: get Borderlands 2.My rating: 8.5/10

												I imagine that Gearbox keep a box in their studio which contains nothing but pistachio shells. No one ever acknowledges the box. They just go along with it. It eats them up inside until they have to ask, at which point they are sacrificed by the rest of the dev team for questioning the box. This goes on for years; the exact source of the cube of death a mystery. It will never end and the box will always be. Eventually someone will work up the courage and finally challenge the others about the box, and the nightmare will end. C'est la vie and all that.Yeah, game's alright. Haven't played it long because Herbert Morrsion constantly uses the computer to download slasher flicks and episodes of play your cards right where you can see Bruce Forsyth's package. Whoever that is.

content:
er 6, 2013
												This game is near flawless. With exciting AND addictive game-play that stays fresh even past the 2nd play-through I am never bored with this Game. Especially considering how easy it really is to play with Friends. I do wish it was more possible for people of different Level ranges to play together but we cant have it all.In stark contrast to the first Borderlands, the story is actually compelling and the superb voice acting makes it hard not to be drawn in. The Humor plays a big part as well and never feels out of place in the abstract Borderlands Universe.The Graphics look great on both high and mid range Systems, offering highly stylized Graphics that still have a touch of Realism. In closing I must commend Gearbox Software for their love-letter to the PC community. This Game truly deserved Game of the Year. “You're gonna be my new meat bicycle!” 100/100
